ParetoTI 0.1.3
  • Reference
  • Articles
    • Manual for Pareto front and task inference, ParetoTI R package

Match/align arhetypes

align_arc.Rd

align_arc() matches archetypes in arc2 to arc1 by exhaustively testing all possible pairings.

gen_permut() used for exhaustive search generates a matrix of all possible permutations of n elements. Each row is a different permutation.

align_arc_opt() does the same as align_arc() but using optimisation (method = "SANN") instead of exhaustively trying all combinations.

align_arc(arc1, arc2)

gen_permut(n)

align_arc_opt(arc1, arc2, control = list(maxit = 10000, temp = 2000,
  REPORT = 500))

Arguments

arc1

reference matrix of archetype positions dim(dimensions, archetypes)
arc2

matrix of archetype positions dim(dimensions, archetypes) to be aligned with arc1
n

number of element to permute
control

options for SANN methods. See optim

Value

align_arc() list containing: total distance between archetypes in arc1 and arc2 (dist), integer vector specifying indices (columns) of arc2 that match archetypes in arc1 (ind)

gen_permut() a matrix of all possible gen_permut (in rows)

same as align_arc()

Details

Exhaustive search works better than optimisation using SANN method for k=2:9 (163.0747ms vs 354.6311ms for 3 dimensions, k=2:5 are faster than 2ms). This optimisation method essentially samples the space rather than doing gradient descent. This is because total distance as a function of pairings of archetypes is not a differentiable function. For this reason, optimisation will often fail to find correct pairing.

gen_permut() function is taken from https://stackoverflow.com/questions/11095992/generating-all-distinct-permutations-of-a-list-in-r

Examples

# Generate data
set.seed(4355)
archetypes = generate_arc(arc_coord = list(c(5, 0), c(-10, 15), c(-30, -20)),
                          mean = 0, sd = 1, N_dim = 2)
#> Error in generate_arc(arc_coord = list(c(5, 0), c(-10, 15), c(-30, -20)),     mean = 0, sd = 1, N_dim = 2): unused argument (N_dim = 2)
data = generate_data(archetypes, N_examples = 1e4, jiiter = 0.04, size = 0.9)
#> Error in ncol(archetypes): object 'archetypes' not found
dim(data)
#> NULL
# fit polytopes to 2 subsamples of the data
arc_data = fit_pch_bootstrap(data, n = 2, sample_prop = 0.65, seed = 2543,
                        order_by_side = F, noc = as.integer(6),
                        delta = 0, type = "s")
#> Error in if (useHash) .Internal(sample2(n, size)) else .Internal(sample(n,     size, replace, prob)): missing value where TRUE/FALSE needed
# align archetypes by exhausive search
align_arc(arc_data$pch_fits$XC[[1]], arc_data$pch_fits$XC[[2]])
#> Error in all.equal(dim(arc1), dim(arc2)): object 'arc_data' not found
# align archetypes by optimisation
set.seed(123)
align_arc_opt(arc_data$pch_fits$XC[[1]], arc_data$pch_fits$XC[[2]])
#> Error in ncol(archetypes): object 'arc_data' not found
# restart multiple times to see if it finds real match
res = lapply(seq(1, 100), function(i) align_arc_opt(arc_data$pch_fits$XC[[1]], arc_data$pch_fits$XC[[2]]))
#> Error in ncol(archetypes): object 'arc_data' not found
# show best pairing
res[[which.min(sapply(res, function(r) r$dist))]]
#> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'res' not found

# Measure which approach is faster depending on k (uncomment)
#for (i in 2:12) {
#    # fit polytopes to 2 subsamples
#    arc_data = fit_pch_bootstrap(data, n = 2, sample_prop = 0.65, seed = 2543,
#                             order_by_side = F, noc = as.integer(i),
#                             delta = 0, type = "s")
#    print(i)
#    # measure how much time each method takes
#    print(microbenchmark::microbenchmark(align_arc(arc_data$pch_fits$XC[[1]], arc_data$pch_fits$XC[[2]]),
#                                         align_arc_opt(arc_data$pch_fits$XC[[1]], arc_data$pch_fits$XC[[2]]),
#                                         times = 10))
#}
